items.title: Remove crashing cross-built aarch64 wheel, in favor of working native builds
items.body:
OS: Ubuntu 18.04.4
Architecture: aarch64, on Amazon AWS c6 instance

The wheel for aarch64 on PyPI provides a non-functioning binary:

```
$ pip install cmake
Collecting cmake
  Using cached cmake-3.18.0-py3-none-manylinux2014_aarch64.whl (15.1 MB)
Installing collected packages: cmake
Successfully installed cmake-3.18.0
$ which cmake
/home/ubuntu/venv-cmake/bin/cmake
$ cmake --version
$ echo $?
245
```

This seems to be related to the discussion on [this issue](https://github.com/scikit-build/cmake-python-distributions/issues/96)

Forcing installation not to use the wheel provides a working binary:

```
$ pip install --no-binary :all: cmake
Collecting cmake
  Using cached cmake-3.18.0.tar.gz (28 kB)
Skipping wheel build for cmake, due to binaries being disabled for it.
Installing collected packages: cmake
    Running setup.py install for cmake ... done
Successfully installed cmake-3.18.0
$ which cmake
/home/ubuntu/venv-cmake/bin/cmake
$ cmake --version
cmake version 3.18.0

CMake suite maintained and supported by Kitware (kitware.com/cmake).
```

Thus, I'm asking that until the build issues are resolved, they be avoided so that users get a working result

items.title: cmake modules are not installed

labels.name: Status: No Action
labels.description: When the resolution is to not do anything

items.body: Please include cmake modules also in the installation setup. This is typically useful for Ubuntu users which has old version of cmake in its `apt` repository.

items.title: Installing cmake on aarch64 using pip via wheel
items.body:
**Summary**
Installing cmake on aarch64 linux platform via pip using command "pip3 install cmake" tries to build wheel from source code.

**Problem description**
Cmake don't have wheel for aarch64 on PyPI repository. So, while installing cmake via pip on aarch64, it builds wheel from source which takes more time to install cmake. Making wheel available for aarch64 will benefit aarch64 users by minimizing installation time.

**Expected Output**
Pip should be able to download cmake wheel from PyPI repository rather than building it from source code.

@thewtex ,  I was able to build wheel with command "python setup.py bdist_wheel" and wheel has been created for specific python version in dist folder. I have tried installing in aarch64 linux platform with command "pip install cmake-xxx.whl", it got installed successfully. Please let me know if any help required in building wheel and uploading it to PyPI repository.

items.title: Documentation and Readme say that the python wheels provide 3.16, but only 3.15 is available
items.body: Hi! I think something might have been missed. It looks like the 3.16 release never occurred? PyPI says the last release was CMake 3.15.3 in September of 2019, which disagrees with what the readme currently states.

items.title: manylinux2010_i686 wheels
items.body:
I notice that the manylinux cmake wheels on pypi are only build for x64_64 architectures. Is there any chance we could also get i686 wheels as well?

I'm currently trying to `pip install cmake` on the manylinux2010_i686 docker image, but because there are no wheels explicitly built for it it tries to install the source wheel. However, to build the source wheel it requires a newer version of cmake than the version provided by centos.

items.title: Build manylinux1 wheel for Python 3.8 and cmake 3.13.2
items.body:
cmake 3.12.2 is the last version offering `manylinux1` due to new versions requiring 2010 `libuv` support. So when scikit-build uses cmake to build `manylinux1` wheels, it uses this version.

However, now that Python 3.8 is available, you cannot use scikit-build for `manylinux1` because there is no 3.8 `manylinux1` wheel for cmake. This **needs to be fixed** by having `cmake-3.12.2-cp38-manylinux1.whl`.

items.title: Install: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'skbuild'
items.body:
We have the following problem when trying to install 3.15.2:

```
pip install cmake --upgrade
Collecting cmake
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/59/20/d1c7e0df29789e7c3aaef17d9952ed477d197cdb4e72d5e23beaf7f3e0c4/cmake-3.15.2.tar.gz
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/private/var/folders/17/5mc7816d3mndxjqgplq6057w0000gn/T/pip-install-yng873yt/cmake/setup.py", line 7, in <module>
        from skbuild import setup
    ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'skbuild'
```

We did not have such a problem with earlier versions.
Installing `scikit-build` via pip before installing `cmake` seems to fix this issue.

It's likely just missed in the dependency list of CMake?

// @ericLemanissier

items.title: CMake 3.15?
items.body: Is updating this in the plans? Let me know if there's something I can do to help.

items.title: Revisit use of manylinux2010 to build wheel
items.body:
### Background:

We started building the cmake wheel using manylinux2010 because, the latest version of cmake couldn't be built using manylinux1.

At first, only providing manylinux2010 wheel for the latest cmake was preventing `pip install cmake` done from a manylinux1 environment from downloading the latest wheel available for that platform, indeed, by default, pip prefer building the latest sdist instead of downloading the latest wheel for that platform. This is discussed in https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/6550. 

For an example of project that faced that problem, see equinor/dlisio#116 and https://github.com/scikit-build/cmake-python-distributions/issues/76

To address, this, the sdist associated with cmake 3.14.3 and 3.14.4 were removed from pypi (note that sdist of 3.13.3 was also removed but this was not strictly required).



### Next step

As suggested in https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/cmake/issues/19311, we could look into building cmake against a version of an older libuv library built on manylinux1.

items.title: Generate wheels without python ABI
items.body:
This will allow to:
* be forward compatible with upcoming version of python
* reduce the number of wheels to generate and upload on PyPi

For example, instead of 

```
cmake-3.13.3-cp27-cp27m-manylinux1_i686.whl
```

wheels would be name like

```
cmake-X.Y.Z-py2.py3-none-manylinux2010_x86_64.whl
```

or 

```
cmake-X.Y.Z-py2-none-manylinux2010_x86_64.whl
cmake-X.Y.Z-py3-none-manylinux2010_x86_64.whl
```

Generating one wheel for each py2 and py3 is a way to test used for both python2 and python3 with minimal effort.

See also https://github.com/scikit-build/scikit-build/issues/420

items.title: No such file or directory: '/tmp/pip-build-env-e2vjq07w/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cmake/data/bin/cmake'

```
No such file or directory: '/tmp/pip-build-env-e2vjq07w/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cmake/data/bin/cmake'
```
Full log:

https://gitlab.com/certik/lfortran/-/jobs/214005303

I don't know why that would be.

items.title: Installation problem in virtualenv with system site packages

labels.name: Status: No Action
labels.description: When the resolution is to not do anything

items.body:
`cmake` executable has wrong shebang if installed in virtualenv with system site packages.

Steps to reproduce:
```shell
$ python3 -m venv --system-site-packages ~/.virtualenv/cmake
$ source ~/.virtualenv/cmake/bin/activate
$ pip3 install cmake
$ head -n1 ~/.virtualenv/cmake/bin/cmake
#!/usr/local/opt/python/bin/python3.7
$ ~/.virtualenv/cmake/bin/cmake
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/hombit/.virtualenv/cmake/bin/cmake", line 7, in <module>
    from cmake import cmake
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'cmake'
```

```shell
$ python3 --version
Python 3.7.2
$ pip3 --version
pip 18.1 from /Users/hombit/.virtualenv/cmake/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pip (python 3.7)
```

items.title: Can't use cmake as setup_requires on Linux.
items.body:
Hi, I'm not sure if this is something that can be fixed within the cmake package, but I can't use the cmake as a prerequisite to build another extension-module-as-a-pip-package 

Here's a minimal setup.py to reproduce this:
```
from setuptools import setup
from distutils.command.build import build as _build
import os
import subprocess

class build(_build):
    def run(self):
        _build.run(self)
        import cmake
        subprocess.check_call([os.path.join(cmake.CMAKE_BIN_DIR, "cmake"),
            "--version",
        ])

setup(
    name="foobar",
    version="1.0.0",
    cmdclass={'build': build},
    setup_requires=["cmake>=3.12"])
```

CMake is not a regular install_requires, because it's not needed when foobar is used (it should already been build by then).  CMake isn't needed when foobar is installed as binary wheel.  But it is required when building the foobar extension module from source code.

However, setup_requires will simply unpack the cmake dependency in an .eggs folder (next to setup.py), and it turns out the permissions of the binaries will be wrong:

```
$ ls .eggs/cmake-3.13.3-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/cmake/data/bin/ -alh
total 31M
drwxr-xr-x 2 bdegreve users    5 Jan 23 19:22 .
drwxr-xr-x 5 bdegreve users    5 Jan 23 19:22 ..
-rw-r--r-- 1 bdegreve users 9.7M Jan 23 19:22 cmake
-rw-r--r-- 1 bdegreve users  10M Jan 23 19:22 cpack
-rw-r--r-- 1 bdegreve users  11M Jan 23 19:22 ctest
```

I tried this on Debian Stretch, with both python 2.7 and python 3.5. It's failing in both cases.
On Windows this works just fine.

items.title: Python 3.7 wheels release
items.body:
Is there any prospect of having Python 3.7 wheels released soon enough?
I am using this project to install CMake within the manylinux docker image to build my own project. As I was updating that setup to now build 3.7 wheels, I get an error (because the source distribution is trying to get installed, instead of the 3.7 wheel).

But I do notice that Python 3.7 wheels are already being built by CircleCI, for this project?

Thanks a lot for these CMake wheels, by the way; so much easier to quickly install CMake! :-)

items.title: Provide CMake 3.11
items.body: Pip install is a great way to suggest someone get a new CMake version; it would be great if 3.11 was available here too.

items.title: Binaries are not stripped
items.body: Using the current `cmake==0.9.0` package from PyPI, I realised that the binaries are not stripped. Calling `strip` manually on the ones residing in `lib/python3.5/site-packages/cmake/data/bin/`, I could save 5 MiB each, i.e. 15MiB in total. It would be nice if we were able to get this incorportated into the wheel itself.

items.title: Issue building on AppVeyor
items.body: The recent AppVeyor builds fail with `from setuptools import monkey` on Python 3.3. and 3.4. I think a reasonable solution would be to drop these from the build, and then rename the output to a general version for all pythons (asked for for 3.6 support). So both issues could potentially be solved at the same time.

items.title: Support for CMake 3.8
items.body:
CMake 3.8 is out, with native support for CUDA as a language. I'd love to see this updated to CMake 3.8.
Cheers!

items.title: https download is broken when using the manylinux wheels
items.body:
Given the file `cmake-test-https-download.cmake`:
```cmake
file(
  DOWNLOAD https://cmake.org/files/v3.7/cmake-3.7.0-SHA-256.txt ./cmake-3.7.0-SHA-256.txt
  SHOW_PROGRESS
  STATUS status
  )

message("status:${status}")
```

It fails with the following:

```bash
$ cmake -P cmake-test-https-download.cmake 
status:1;"Unsupported protocol"
```
